name: Shrimp Fry
steps: 1) Marinate shrimp with garlic, pepper, salt.
2) Pan fry until golden.
3) Serve hot.

name: Malai Kofta
steps: For koftas, mix grated paneer, mashed potatoes, corn flour, salt, and chopped cashews/raisins.
Shape into small balls and deep fry on medium heat until golden. Set aside.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Add cashew paste and cook for 2–3 minutes.
Add water to adjust gravy consistency and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add cream, garam masala, sugar, and crushed kasuri methi. Mix gently.
Just before serving, add fried koftas to the gravy and simmer for 1–2 minutes.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or jeera rice.

name: Mutton Biryani
steps: 1) Marinate mutton and cook halfway.
2) Parboil rice.
3) Layer both with onions and ghee.
4) Dum cook for 25 min.

name: Chicken 65
steps: 1) Marinate chicken with all ingredients.
2) Deep fry until crispy.
3) Toss with curry leaves and serve.

name: Mutton Rogan Josh
steps: 1) Heat oil and sear mutton.
2) Add yogurt, spices, and stir.
3) Add water and slow-cook until tender.
4) Serve hot with rice or naan.

name: Egg Curry
steps: 1) Make masala with onion, tomato, spices.
2) Add water and simmer.
3) Add boiled eggs and cook 5 minutes.

name: Chicken Fried Rice
steps: 1) Scramble egg, set aside.
2) Stir-fry chicken and peas.
3) Add rice, soy sauce, salt.
4) Mix egg back in and fry 2 minutes.

name: Bhindi Masala
steps: Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan and sauté chopped bhindi on medium flame until non-sticky and partially cooked. Keep aside.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in another pan and add cumin seeds.
Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomatoes, turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until tomatoes turn soft.
Add sautéed bhindi and mix well.
Cook on low flame for 8–10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add garam masala and amchur powder, mix gently.
Serve hot with roti or paratha.

name: Chicken Shawarma
steps: 1) Marinate chicken with all ingredients.
2) Grill or pan-fry 8 minutes.
3) Serve in pita with veggies.

name: Prawn Curry
steps: 1) Sauté onions and garlic.
2) Add prawns and spices.
3) Pour coconut milk and simmer 5 minutes.

name: Fish Fry
steps: 1) Marinate fish with spices and lemon.
2) Pan fry until golden.
3) Serve hot.

name: Chicken Korma
steps: 1) Heat ghee and sauté paste.
2) Add chicken and spices.
3) Add curd and cashew paste.
4) Cook until creamy.

name: Tandoori Chicken
steps: 1) Marinate chicken with all ingredients.
2) Rest 1 hour.
3) Grill or bake at high heat 25 minutes.
4) Serve with lemon wedges.

name: Chicken Biryani
steps: 1) Marinate chicken with curd, masala, and salt.
2) Partially cook rice.
3) Layer rice and chicken with fried onions.
4) Add ghee and cook on dum for 25 minutes.

name: Home Style Chicken Curry
steps: 1) Heat oil and sauté onions until golden.
2) Add ginger-garlic paste and tomatoes.
3) Add spices and cook till oil separates.
4) Add chicken and cook 20 minutes.
5) Garnish and serve.

name: Aloo Tikki
steps: Mash boiled potatoes in a bowl.
Add bread crumbs, green chilies, ginger, coriander leaves, red chili powder, garam masala, coriander powder, amchur, and salt.
Mix well to form a smooth dough-like mixture.
Divide mixture into equal portions and shape into round flat patties (tikkis).
Heat oil on a tawa or pan.
Shallow fry tikkis on both sides until golden brown and crisp.
Serve hot with mint chutney, tamarind chutney, or yogurt.

name: Butter Chicken
steps: 1) Sauté chicken in butter until lightly browned.
2) Add ginger-garlic paste and cook 1 minute.
3) Add tomato puree, chili powder, salt.
4) Simmer 10 minutes.
5) Add cream and garam masala. Cook 2 minutes.

name: Aloo Gobi
steps: 1) Heat oil, add cumin.
2) Add potatoes, cauliflower, spices.
3) Cook covered 15 minutes.

name: Baingan Bharta
steps: 1) Roast eggplant and mash.
2) Fry onions, chili, tomatoes.
3) Add mashed eggplant and cook 5 minutes.

name: Vegetable Korma
steps: 1) Heat oil, sauté onion and ginger-garlic.
2) Add vegetables, spices and cook for 3 minutes.
3) Add coconut milk and simmer 10 minutes.

name: Mushroom Masala
steps: 1) Heat oil, sauté onions.
2) Add ginger-garlic paste and tomato puree.
3) Add mushrooms and spices.
4) Cook 5–7 minutes.

name: Kachori
steps: Mix maida, salt, and 2 tbsp oil/ghee. Add water gradually and knead into a soft dough. Rest for 20 minutes.
Drain soaked moong dal and coarsely grind it.
Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan. Add cumin, fennel seeds, and hing.
Add ground dal and sauté for 3–4 minutes.
Add red chili, coriander powder, garam masala, amchur, and salt. Cook until fragrant and dry. Cool the stuffing.
Divide dough into small balls and flatten slightly.
Place stuffing in the center, seal edges, and shape into a ball.
Gently roll or press into a small disc.
Deep fry on low-medium flame until golden and crisp.
Serve hot with tamarind chutney or aloo sabzi.

name: Aloo Matar
steps: 1) Heat oil, sauté ginger-garlic paste.
2) Add tomato puree and spices.
3) Add potatoes and peas.
4) Add water and cook until potatoes soften.

name: Paneer Bhurji
steps: 1) Heat oil, sauté onions.
2) Add tomatoes, chili, spices.
3) Add paneer and cook 3 minutes.
4) Serve with roti or pav.

name: Dal Tadka
steps: 1) Pressure cook dal with turmeric.
2) Heat ghee, add cumin, garlic, red chili.
3) Pour tadka over dal.
4) Simmer 2 minutes and serve hot.

name: Kadai Paneer
steps: 1) Heat oil, sauté onions until translucent.
2) Add ginger-garlic paste and capsicum.
3) Add tomato puree, kadai masala, salt.
4) Add paneer and simmer 3–4 minutes.
5) Serve with roti or naan.

name: Kadhi Pakoda
steps: To make pakoras, mix besan, sliced onions, green chilies, salt, and a little water into a thick batter.
Heat oil and fry small portions of batter until golden brown. Keep aside.
For kadhi, whisk curd, besan, turmeric, salt, and water until smooth.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, curry leaves, and grated ginger.
Pour the curd-besan mixture into the pan and bring to a gentle boil.
Cook on low flame for 20–25 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add red chili powder and coriander powder.
Add fried pakoras to the kadhi and simmer for 5 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice or roti.

name: Shahi Paneer
steps: Heat oil and ghee in a pan. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add soaked cashews and cook for 2 minutes.
Cool the mixture and grind into a smooth paste.
Pour the paste back into the pan and add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt.
Add milk and simmer for 5 minutes on low flame.
Add paneer cubes and cook for 3–4 minutes.
Add cream and crushed kasuri methi. Mix gently.
Serve hot with naan, kulcha, or jeera rice.

name: Paneer Tikka Masala
steps: 1) Marinate paneer cubes with yogurt, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, garam masala and salt. Set aside for 30 minutes.
2) Heat oil in a pan, add tomato puree and cook until oil separates.
3) Add marinated paneer, cream, adjust salt, cook for 5-7 minutes on low heat.
4) Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with naan or rice.

name: Vegetarian Lasagna
steps: 1) Pre-heat oven to 180 °C.
2) Lightly sauté mixed vegetables and spinach in 1 tbsp olive oil until just tender.
3) In a baking dish, layer marinara sauce, lasagna sheets, vegetable mixture, ricotta, mozzarella — repeat to make 3 layers.
4) Top with remaining mozzarella and bake for 25-30 minutes until golden and bubbling.
5) Let rest 5 minutes, slice and serve hot.

name: Dal Makhani
steps: Pressure cook soaked urad dal and rajma with salt for 6–7 whistles until soft.
Heat oil and butter in a pan. Add onions and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, red chili powder, turmeric, and garam masala. Cook until oil separates.
Add boiled dal-rajma mixture and mix well.
Simmer on low flame for 20–30 minutes, stirring occasionally for creaminess.
Add cream and crushed kasuri methi. Simmer for 5 more minutes.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or jeera rice.

name: Veg Pulao
steps: 1) Heat ghee/oil in a pot. Add whole spices and sauté for a few seconds.
2) Add sliced onions and fry until golden.
3) Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili; sauté for 1 minute.
4) Add mixed vegetables and stir-fry for 3 minutes.
5) Add soaked rice, water, and salt. Mix gently.
6) Cover and cook on low heat for 12–15 minutes until rice is done.
7) Fluff and serve hot with raita.

name: Shahi Tukda
steps: 1) Heat milk in a pan, simmer until slightly thick. Add 3 tbsp sugar and cardamom. Stir and cook for 5–7 minutes to make rabri.
2) In another pan, mix 1/2 cup sugar and 1/4 cup water. Boil for 2–3 minutes until a thin syrup forms.
3) Cut bread slices into triangles and fry them in ghee until golden and crisp.
4) Dip fried bread briefly in sugar syrup.
5) Place the soaked bread on a plate, pour warm rabri on top.
6) Garnish with saffron and chopped nuts. Serve warm or chilled.

name: Banana Ice Cream
steps: 1) Slice the ripe bananas and place them in an airtight container.
2) Freeze for at least 4 hours or until completely solid.
3) Add frozen banana slices to a blender or food processor and blend until smooth and creamy.
4) Add a splash of milk or cream if needed for a creamier texture.
5) Serve immediately as soft serve, or freeze for 1 hour for a firmer texture.

name: No-Bake Cheesecake
steps: 1) Mix crushed biscuits and melted butter until combined. Press into the base of a springform pan to form the crust. Chill for 20 minutes.
2) In a bowl, beat cream cheese, sugar, vanilla extract, and lemon juice until smooth and creamy.
3) Gently fold in the whipped cream until fully incorporated.
4) Pour the mixture over the chilled crust and smooth the top with a spatula.
5) Cover and refrigerate for at least 4–5 hours (or overnight) until firm.
6) Top with fruit compote or sauce before serving.

name: Chocolate Mousse
steps: 1) Melt dark chocolate in a double boiler or microwave in short bursts. Let it cool slightly.
2) In a large chilled bowl, whip the cream with sugar and vanilla extract until soft peaks form.
3) Gently fold the melted chocolate into the whipped cream using a spatula. Mix until smooth and even.
4) Spoon the mousse into serving cups and refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
5) Serve chilled, topped with whipped cream or grated chocolate.

name: Chocolate Brownie
steps: 1) Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F). Grease and line a baking pan with parchment paper.
2) In a bowl, whisk melted butter and sugar until combined. Add eggs and vanilla extract, whisk until smooth.
3) Sift in flour, cocoa powder, and salt. Fold gently until no dry flour remains.
4) Add chocolate chips if using and mix lightly.
5) Pour the batter into the prepared pan and spread evenly.
6) Bake for 25–30 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out with a few moist crumbs.
7) Cool completely, cut into squares, and serve.

name: Besan Ladoo
steps: 1) Heat ghee in a heavy pan over low flame. Add besan and roast slowly, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
2) Continue roasting for 15–20 minutes until the besan turns golden brown and gives a nutty aroma.
3) Turn off the heat and let it cool slightly (lukewarm).
4) Add powdered sugar, cardamom powder, and chopped nuts. Mix well until the mixture binds together.
5) Shape into round ladoos while the mixture is still warm.
6) Let them cool completely before storing in an airtight container.

name: Kheer (Rice Pudding)
steps: 1) Bring milk to a boil in a heavy-bottomed pan. Reduce heat and let it simmer.
2) Add soaked rice and cook on low flame, stirring occasionally, until the rice is soft and the milk thickens (about 30 minutes).
3) Add sugar, cardamom powder, and saffron milk. Stir well until sugar dissolves completely.
4) Add chopped nuts and raisins. Simmer for another 5 minutes.
5) Serve hot or chilled, garnished with more dry fruits or saffron strands.

name: Rasmalai
steps: 1) Boil milk in a heavy pan. When it starts boiling, add diluted lemon juice gradually and stir until milk curdles.
2) Drain the curds using a muslin cloth, rinse with cold water, and hang for 30 minutes to remove excess whey — this forms the chenna.
3) Knead the chenna gently into a smooth dough and shape into small flat discs.
4) In a wide pan, boil 3 cups of water with 1 cup sugar. Drop the discs in and cook covered for 12–15 minutes until they double in size.
5) In another pan, boil 500 ml milk until slightly thickened. Add saffron, sugar (3 tbsp), and cardamom powder. Simmer for 5 minutes.
6) Squeeze the cooked rasgullas gently to remove syrup and transfer into the warm saffron milk.
7) Garnish with chopped almonds and pistachios. Chill before serving.

name: Gulab Jamun
steps: 1) In a bowl, combine grated khoya, maida, and baking soda. Mix gently.
2) Add milk gradually and knead into a soft, smooth dough. Avoid over-kneading.
3) Divide the dough into small round balls without cracks. Set aside.
4) In a pan, boil sugar and water to make syrup. Add cardamom and rose water, then keep it warm.
5) Heat ghee in a deep pan on low flame. Fry the balls slowly until golden brown all over.
6) Transfer immediately to warm sugar syrup and soak for at least 30 minutes.
7) Serve warm or at room temperature, garnished with pistachios or saffron.

name: Malabar Parotta
steps: 1) In a large bowl, combine maida, sugar, and salt. Add lukewarm milk and water gradually to knead a soft, elastic dough.
2) Add 1 tbsp oil and knead again for a few minutes. Cover and rest for at least 1 hour.
3) Divide the dough into equal balls and coat each with oil. Let rest for another 15 minutes.
4) Roll one dough ball as thin as possible (almost transparent). Brush with oil, then fold or pleat it like a fan.
5) Coil the pleated dough into a spiral, flatten slightly, and roll gently again into a thick parotta.
6) Heat a tawa or griddle and cook each parotta on both sides with oil until golden and flaky.
7) Lightly crush the parotta between your hands to separate layers. Serve hot with vegetable kurma or chicken curry.

name: Lachha Paratha
steps: 1) In a bowl, mix whole wheat flour and salt. Gradually add water and knead into a soft, smooth dough. Cover and rest for 15 minutes.
2) Divide the dough into equal portions and roll one portion into a thin circle using dry flour for dusting.
3) Brush ghee evenly over the surface and sprinkle a little dry flour on top.
4) Pleat the rolled dough like a fan or roll it into a spiral. Flatten gently and roll again into a circle, keeping the layers visible.
5) Heat a tawa and cook the paratha on both sides with ghee until golden and crisp.
6) Lightly press the paratha from the edges while roasting to separate the layers.
7) Serve hot with any curry, dal, or raita.

name: Sattu Paratha
steps: 1) In a bowl, mix whole wheat flour and water to knead a soft dough. Cover and rest for 10–15 minutes.
2) In another bowl, combine sattu, onion, green chili, ginger, lemon juice, mustard oil, ajwain, and salt. Mix well — the filling should be slightly moist but crumbly.
3) Divide the dough and filling into equal portions.
4) Roll one dough ball slightly, place the sattu filling in the center, and seal the edges tightly.
5) Roll gently into a round paratha (6–7 inches in diameter).
6) Cook on a tawa with ghee on both sides until golden and crisp.
7) Serve hot with curd, pickle, or chokha (mashed spiced vegetables).

name: Keema Paratha
steps: 1) Heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan. Add ginger-garlic paste and onion, and sauté until golden.
2) Add minced meat, red chili powder, turmeric, garam masala, green chili, and salt. Cook until the meat is browned and dry. Let it cool.
3) In another bowl, mix wheat flour, salt, and water to knead a soft dough. Rest for 10 minutes.
4) Divide the dough and cooled keema mixture into equal portions.
5) Roll one dough ball slightly, place the stuffing in the center, and seal the edges.
6) Roll gently into a round paratha (about 6 inches).
7) Cook on a hot tawa using ghee or oil until golden brown on both sides.
8) Serve hot with raita, curd, or chutney.

name: Matar Paratha
steps: 1) Boil or steam green peas until soft. Drain and mash coarsely.
2) In a bowl, mix mashed peas with ginger, green chili, coriander powder, garam masala, red chili powder, and salt. Set aside.
3) In another bowl, mix wheat flour, salt, and water to knead a soft dough. Rest for 10 minutes.
4) Divide dough and stuffing into equal portions.
5) Roll out a small circle of dough, place the stuffing in the center, and seal the edges.
6) Roll gently into a round paratha (6–7 inches).
7) Cook on a tawa using oil or ghee until golden brown spots appear on both sides.
8) Serve hot with curd or butter.

name: Pyaaz Paratha
steps: 1) Mix whole wheat flour, salt, and enough water to knead a soft dough. Rest for 10–15 minutes.
2) In a bowl, combine chopped onions, green chili, coriander, ajwain, red chili powder, amchur, and salt to make the stuffing.
3) Divide dough and stuffing into equal portions.
4) Roll one dough ball slightly, place stuffing in the center, and seal the edges.
5) Roll gently into a round paratha (about 6 inches).
6) Heat a tawa and cook paratha on both sides with oil or ghee until golden and crisp.
7) Serve hot with curd, butter, or pickle.

name: Methi Paratha
steps: 1) In a large mixing bowl, combine chopped methi leaves, green chili, cumin seeds, red chili powder, turmeric, and salt.
2) Add whole wheat flour to the mixture and mix well with your hands.
3) Gradually add water to form a soft, pliable dough. Rest it for 10–15 minutes.
4) Divide the dough into equal balls and roll each into a round paratha (6–7 inches in diameter).
5) Heat a tawa and cook the paratha on both sides using oil or ghee until golden brown spots appear.
6) Serve hot with curd, pickle, or butter.

name: Mooli Paratha

ingredients.name: white radish
ingredients.note: grated and squeezed to remove excess water

steps: 1) Prepare dough by mixing wheat flour, salt, and water. Knead into a soft dough and rest for 10–15 minutes.
2) Grate radish and squeeze out the excess water completely to avoid soggy parathas.
3) In a bowl, mix grated radish, green chili, coriander, ajwain, red chili powder, and salt to make the stuffing.
4) Divide dough and stuffing into equal portions.
5) Roll out a small dough ball, place stuffing in the center, seal, and roll gently into a round paratha.
6) Cook on a hot tawa using oil or ghee until golden brown on both sides.
7) Serve hot with curd, butter, or pickle.

name: Gobi Paratha
steps: 1) In a bowl, mix wheat flour, a pinch of salt, and water. Knead into a soft dough and rest for 10 minutes.
2) In another bowl, mix grated cauliflower, green chili, ginger, coriander leaves, red chili powder, ajwain, and salt to prepare the filling.
3) Divide dough and filling into equal portions.
4) Roll one dough ball slightly, place the stuffing in the center, and bring the edges together to seal.
5) Roll gently into a round paratha about 6 inches in diameter.
6) Heat a tawa and cook the paratha on both sides with oil or ghee until golden brown spots appear.
7) Serve hot with curd, butter, or pickle.

name: Paneer Paratha
steps: 1) Mix whole wheat flour, a pinch of salt, and water to knead a soft dough. Rest it for 10–15 minutes.
2) In a bowl, mix grated paneer, green chili, coriander leaves, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt to make the stuffing.
3) Divide dough and filling into equal portions.
4) Roll one dough ball slightly, place stuffing in the center, and seal the edges tightly.
5) Flatten gently and roll into a round paratha (6–7 inches).
6) Heat a tawa, cook paratha on both sides with oil or ghee until golden brown.
7) Serve hot with butter, curd, or pickle.

name: Aloo Paratha
steps: In a bowl, add wheat flour, a pinch of salt, and water(as needed). Knead into a soft dough and rest for 15 minutes.
In another bowl, mix mashed potatoes, green chilies, coriander, red chili powder, garam masala, amchur powder, and salt to make stuffing.
Divide dough into equal portions and roll each into a small circle.
Place a spoonful of stuffing in the center and seal edges properly.
Gently roll out stuffed dough into a round paratha.
Heat tawa and roast the paratha on both sides with ghee or oil until golden brown.
Serve hot with butter, curd, or pickle.

name: Paneer Butter Masala
steps: Heat oil and 1 tbsp butter in a pan. Add onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree and cook until the mixture thickens and oil separates.
Add cashew paste, red chili powder, turmeric, salt, and garam masala. Cook for 3–4 minutes.
Pour water to adjust consistency and bring to a simmer.
Add paneer cubes and cook for 5 minutes on low flame.
Stir in remaining butter, cream, and crushed kasuri methi.
Serve hot with naan, roti, or jeera rice.

name: Rajma Chawal
steps: Soak rajma overnight and pressure cook with salt until soft (4-5 whistles).
Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, chili, coriander powder, and garam masala. Cook until oil separates.
Add boiled rajma with its water and simmer for 15–20 minutes until thick and flavorful.
Mash some rajma for a thicker consistency if desired.
Garnish with coriander leaves and serve hot with steamed rice.

name: Chole
steps: Soak chickpeas overnight and pressure cook them with salt until soft (about 4-5 whistles).
Heat oil in a pan and add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomato puree, turmeric, chili powder, and chole masala. Cook until oil separates.
Add boiled chickpeas with some of their water and simmer for 10–15 minutes.
Mash a few chickpeas for thicker gravy if desired.
Garnish with coriander leaves and serve hot with bhature or rice.

name: Lemon Sherbet (Nimbu Sharbat)
steps: 1) In a glass, mix lemon juice and sugar.
2) Add chilled water and stir until sugar fully dissolves.
3) Optionally add a pinch of salt or black salt for tanginess.
4) Serve immediately with ice cubes and a slice of lemon.

name: Khaman Dhokla
steps: 1) Grease a steaming tray with oil and keep it ready.
2) In a mixing bowl, combine gram flour, semolina, yogurt, lemon juice, sugar, and salt.
3) Add water gradually to make a smooth, thick batter. Let it rest for 10–15 minutes.
4) Heat water in a steamer. Just before steaming, add eno fruit salt to the batter and mix gently.
5) Pour the batter into the greased tray and steam for 15–20 minutes on medium heat until a toothpick comes out clean.
6) Allow the dhokla to cool slightly before cutting it into squares.
7) For tempering, heat oil in a small pan, add mustard seeds, green chilies, and curry leaves. Let them splutter.
8) Add ¼ cup water and 1 tsp sugar to the tempering, and pour it evenly over the cut dhokla.
9) Garnish with chopped coriander and serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Peanut Butter Cookies
steps: 1) Preheat oven to 180°C (350°F) and line a baking tray with parchment paper.
2) In a bowl, mix peanut butter, sugar, and egg until a smooth dough forms.
3) Roll small balls of dough, place on the tray, and flatten gently with a fork in a criss-cross pattern.
4) Bake for 8–10 minutes until edges turn golden.
5) Cool on a wire rack before serving.

name: Chilli Garlic Noodles
steps: 1) Boil noodles as per instructions until just cooked. Drain and rinse with cold water. Toss with 1 tsp oil to prevent sticking.
2) Heat oil in a wok on high flame.
3) Add dry red chilies and chopped garlic. Stir-fry for 30 seconds until fragrant and slightly crisp.
4) Add spring onion whites, carrot, and capsicum. Stir-fry on high heat for 2–3 minutes.
5) Add soy sauce, vinegar, chili sauce, salt, and black pepper. Mix well.
6) Add boiled noodles and toss everything together quickly on high heat to coat evenly in sauces.
7) Add spring onion greens and give a final toss.
8) Serve hot immediately with extra chili sauce on the side.

name: Jeera Rice
steps: 1) Rinse basmati rice until the water runs clear and soak for 15 minutes.
2) In a pot or pan, heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Let them splutter and turn aromatic.
3) Add the drained rice and sauté gently for a minute.
4) Pour in 2 cups of water, add salt if desired, and cook until rice is fluffy and water is absorbed.
5) Fluff with a fork and serve hot with dal or curry.

name: Veg Spring Roll

ingredients.name: corn flour slurry
ingredients.note: mix 1 tbsp corn flour in 3 tbsp water for sealing

steps: 1) Heat 2 tbsp oil in a wok on high flame.
2) Add chopped garlic and sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
3) Add spring onion whites, cabbage, carrot, and capsicum. Stir-fry for 2–3 minutes on high heat.
4) Add soy sauce, vinegar, black pepper, and salt. Mix well and stir-fry for another minute.
5) Turn off heat, add spring onion greens, and let the filling cool completely.
6) Place a spring roll sheet on a flat surface with a corner facing you (diamond shape).
7) Add 2 tbsp of vegetable filling near the bottom corner, fold the bottom over the filling, then fold in both sides.
8) Roll tightly and seal the edge with corn flour slurry.
9) Repeat for all spring rolls and keep covered with a damp cloth.
10) Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the rolls in batches on medium flame until golden and crisp.
11) Drain on paper towels and serve hot with chili sauce or schezwan dip.

name: Chicken Fried Rice
steps: 1) Heat half the oil in a wok on high flame.
2) Add the beaten egg, scramble it quickly, and cook until just set. Remove and set aside.
3) In the same wok, add remaining oil and stir-fry garlic for 30 seconds until fragrant.
4) Add the chicken cubes and stir-fry on high flame for 4–5 minutes until fully cooked and lightly browned.
5) Add chopped carrot, capsicum, and the white part of spring onions. Stir-fry for 2–3 minutes without overcooking.
6) Add soy sauce, vinegar, black pepper, and salt. Mix well.
7) Add cooked rice and toss everything on high flame for 2–3 minutes.
8) Add scrambled eggs back in and mix evenly.
9) Garnish with spring onion greens and serve hot with chili sauce or Manchurian gravy.

name: Veg Hakka Noodles
steps: 1) Boil noodles as per packet instructions until just cooked (al dente). Drain and rinse with cold water to stop cooking.
2) Toss noodles with 1 tsp oil to prevent sticking and set aside.
3) Heat oil in a wok on high flame.
4) Add chopped garlic and slit green chili. Stir-fry for 20 seconds until fragrant.
5) Add the white part of spring onions and all chopped vegetables. Stir-fry on high heat for 2–3 minutes, keeping them crisp.
6) Add soy sauce, vinegar, chili sauce, black pepper, and salt. Mix well.
7) Add the boiled noodles and toss everything together using tongs or chopsticks for 1–2 minutes on high flame.
8) Add spring onion greens, mix again, and turn off the flame.
9) Serve hot immediately with chili sauce or manchurian gravy.

name: Gobi Manchurian

ingredients.name: corn flour slurry
ingredients.note: mix 1 tbsp corn flour in 3 tbsp water

steps: 1) Boil water in a pot with a pinch of salt. Add cauliflower florets and blanch for 2 minutes. Drain and pat dry.
2) In a bowl, mix maida, corn flour, salt, pepper, soy sauce, and a little water to form a thick batter.
3) Dip cauliflower florets in the batter and coat evenly.
4) Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the coated florets on medium heat until golden and crisp. Remove and drain on tissue paper.
5) In a separate wok, heat 1 tbsp oil.
6) Add chopped garlic and green chilies, sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
7) Add onions and capsicum. Stir-fry on high flame for 2–3 minutes.
8) Add soy sauce, chili sauce, tomato ketchup, and vinegar. Mix well.
9) Add 1/4 cup water and bring the sauce to a boil.
10) Stir in corn flour slurry and cook until sauce thickens slightly.
11) Add fried cauliflower pieces and toss well until coated with sauce.
12) Garnish with chopped spring onions and serve hot as a snack or side dish.

name: Chilli Paneer

ingredients.name: corn flour slurry
ingredients.note: mix 1 tbsp corn flour in 3 tbsp water

steps: 1) In a bowl, mix corn flour, maida, salt, pepper, and a few tablespoons of water to make a thick batter.
2) Add paneer cubes and coat them evenly in the batter.
3) Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the coated paneer cubes on medium flame until golden and crisp. Remove and drain on paper towels.
4) Heat 1 tbsp oil in a wok on high flame.
5) Add chopped garlic and slit green chilies. Sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
6) Add cubed onions and capsicum. Stir-fry for 2–3 minutes on high flame until slightly tender but still crisp.
7) Add soy sauce, chili sauce, tomato ketchup, and vinegar. Stir well.
8) Pour in 1/4 cup water and bring to a simmer.
9) Add corn flour slurry to thicken the sauce. Stir continuously until it reaches a glossy consistency.
10) Add fried paneer cubes and toss gently to coat them evenly in the sauce.
11) Garnish with chopped spring onions and serve hot as a starter or with fried rice or noodles.

name: Schezwan Fried Rice
steps: 1) Cook rice until just done, spread it on a plate, and cool completely.
2) Heat oil in a wok on high flame.
3) Add chopped garlic and sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
4) Add the white part of spring onions and chopped vegetables. Stir-fry for 2–3 minutes on high flame without overcooking.
5) Add Schezwan sauce, soy sauce, and vinegar. Mix quickly.
6) Add the cooked rice and toss everything well to combine.
7) Sprinkle black pepper and salt, and stir-fry on high flame for another minute to develop smoky flavor.
8) Garnish with spring onion greens and serve hot with Schezwan chutney or Veg Manchurian.

name: Hakka Noodles
steps: 1) Boil noodles as per packet instructions until just cooked. Drain completely and rinse with cold water to stop cooking.
2) Toss noodles in 1 tsp oil to prevent sticking and set aside.
3) Heat 1.5 tbsp oil in a wok on high flame.
4) Add chopped garlic and green chili. Sauté for 30 seconds.
5) Add the white part of spring onions and stir-fry briefly.
6) Add all the vegetables — carrot, beans, capsicum, and cabbage. Stir-fry on high flame for 2–3 minutes while keeping them crunchy.
7) Add soy sauce, chili sauce, vinegar, salt, and pepper. Mix quickly.
8) Add the boiled noodles and toss everything well to coat evenly in the sauce.
9) Keep tossing on high flame for another minute for a smoky flavor.
10) Garnish with spring onion greens and serve hot immediately.

name: Veg Manchurian

ingredients.name: corn flour slurry
ingredients.note: mix 1 tbsp corn flour in 3 tbsp water

steps: 1) In a mixing bowl, combine grated cabbage, carrot, capsicum, and a bit of chopped spring onions.
2) Add corn flour, maida, soy sauce, pepper, and salt. Mix well and form small balls.
3) Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the balls in batches until golden and crisp. Remove and drain on paper towels.
4) For the sauce, heat 1 tbsp oil in a wok.
5) Add chopped garlic and green chili. Sauté for 30 seconds on high flame.
6) Add the white part of spring onions and stir-fry briefly.
7) Add soy sauce, chili sauce, and tomato ketchup. Stir and cook for a few seconds.
8) Add 1/2 cup water and bring it to a simmer.
9) Add corn flour slurry to thicken the sauce. Stir continuously until it reaches a glossy, medium-thick consistency.
10) Add the fried Manchurian balls and toss well to coat them evenly in the sauce.
11) Garnish with spring onion greens and serve hot with fried rice or noodles.

name: Veg Fried Rice
steps: 1) Cook rice until just done (not mushy), spread on a plate, and let it cool completely.
2) Heat oil in a wok or large pan on high flame.
3) Add the white part of spring onions and sauté for 30 seconds.
4) Add chopped carrots, beans, cabbage, and capsicum. Stir-fry on high flame for 2–3 minutes without overcooking.
5) Add cooked rice and toss everything quickly using a spatula.
6) Add soy sauce, vinegar, salt, and black pepper powder.
7) Mix well so that the sauces coat the rice evenly. Keep the flame high for that smoky wok flavor.
8) Add chopped spring onion greens and toss again.
9) Turn off heat and serve hot with Manchurian or Schezwan sauce.

name: Ven Pongal
steps: 1) Dry roast the moong dal in a pan for 2–3 minutes until aromatic but not browned.
2) Wash the roasted moong dal and rice together in water until clear.
3) Add them to a pressure cooker with 3 cups of water and a pinch of salt.
4) Pressure cook for 4–5 whistles on medium flame until soft and mushy.
5) Once pressure releases, open and mash lightly for a creamy consistency.
6) Heat 2 tbsp ghee in a small pan for tempering.
7) Add cashews and fry until golden, then remove and set aside.
8) In the same ghee, add cumin seeds, crushed peppercorns, chopped ginger, curry leaves, and hing.
9) Fry for a few seconds until fragrant and then pour the tempering into the cooked rice-dal mixture.
10) Mix well, add fried cashews, and stir to combine everything evenly.
11) Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Coconut Chutney
steps: 1) In a blender jar, add grated coconut, roasted chana dal, green chilies, ginger, and salt.
2) Add 1/4 to 1/2 cup water and blend to a smooth paste. Adjust consistency as desired.
3) Transfer the chutney to a serving bowl.
4) For tempering, heat 1 tsp oil in a small pan.
5) Add mustard seeds and let them crackle.
6) Add urad dal and fry until golden.
7) Add dry red chili and curry leaves. Sauté for a few seconds.
8) Pour the tempering over the chutney and mix lightly.
9) Serve immediately with idli, dosa, vada, or upma.

name: Sambar
steps: 1) Wash and pressure cook 0.75 cup toor dal with 2 cups water, turmeric, and a drop of oil for 4–5 whistles until soft.
2) Mash the cooked dal smoothly and set aside.
3) Soak tamarind in 1/2 cup warm water for 10 minutes and extract the pulp. Discard the residue.
4) In a pot, heat 1/2 tbsp oil and sauté onions and tomatoes for 2 minutes.
5) Add chopped vegetables and stir for another 2–3 minutes.
6) Add 1 cup water and cook until the vegetables are tender.
7) Add tamarind pulp, sambar powder, jaggery, and salt. Mix well and simmer for 5 minutes.
8) Add the mashed dal and 1 more cup of water to adjust consistency. Simmer for 8–10 minutes until the flavors blend well.
9) For tempering, heat 1 tbsp oil in a small pan, add mustard seeds, red chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida. Let them crackle.
10) Pour the tempering over the simmering sambar and mix gently.
11) Garnish with chopped coriander and serve hot with idli, dosa, or rice.

name: Uttapam
steps: 1) Mix the idli dosa batter well. Adjust consistency with a few tablespoons of water if it is too thick.
2) In a bowl, combine chopped onions, tomatoes, green chilies, grated carrots, and coriander.
3) Heat a non-stick tawa or iron skillet on medium flame and grease it lightly with oil or ghee.
4) Pour a ladleful of batter and spread it slightly to form a thick pancake about 1/4 inch thick.
5) Sprinkle the mixed vegetables evenly on top of the batter.
6) Drizzle a few drops of oil or ghee around the edges and over the top.
7) Cook on medium flame for 2–3 minutes until the base turns golden brown.
8) Flip carefully and cook the other side for 1–2 minutes until the vegetables are slightly roasted.
9) Remove from the pan and serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Cheese Quesadilla
steps: 1) Heat a pan and lightly butter one side of each tortilla.
2) Place one tortilla, buttered side down, on the pan and sprinkle cheese evenly over it.
3) Cover with the second tortilla, buttered side up.
4) Cook on medium heat until golden brown and cheese melts, flipping once.
5) Slice into wedges and serve warm.

name: Mango Lassi
steps: 1) Add mango pulp, curd, and sugar to a blender.
2) Blend until smooth and creamy.
3) Pour into a glass and chill before serving.
4) Optionally garnish with mint or saffron strands.

name: Boiled Potato Chaat
steps: 1) Peel and cube the boiled potatoes into bite-sized pieces.
2) Add salt and lemon juice, then toss gently to combine.
3) Serve fresh as a light snack or side dish.
4) Optionally, sprinkle a pinch of chili powder or chaat masala for extra flavor.

name: Chocolate Mug Cake
steps: 1) In a microwave-safe mug, mix flour, cocoa powder, and condensed milk until smooth.
2) Add 1–2 tsp of water or milk if needed to adjust consistency.
3) Microwave on high for 1 minute or until the cake rises and sets.
4) Cool slightly and enjoy warm straight from the mug.
5) Optional add some chocolate pieces

name: Poha Chivda
steps: 1) Heat oil in a wide pan on low flame.
2) Add poha and roast gently, stirring continuously until crisp.
3) Add salt and toss well to coat evenly.
4) Cool completely and store in an airtight container.

name: Dalgona Coffee
steps: 1) In a bowl, combine instant coffee, sugar, and 2 tsp of hot water.
2) Whisk or beat the mixture until it becomes thick, frothy, and light brown in color.
3) Pour milk into a glass and spoon the whipped coffee mixture on top.
4) Serve chilled or hot. Stir before drinking for best taste.

name: Garlic Toast
steps: 1) In a small bowl, mix softened butter with crushed garlic.
2) Spread the mixture evenly on both sides of the bread slices.
3) Toast in a pan or oven until golden and crisp.
4) Serve hot as a snack or side dish.

name: Cacio e Pepe
steps: 1) Boil spaghetti in salted water until al dente. Reserve 1/2 cup of pasta water.
2) In a pan, toast crushed black pepper for a few seconds.
3) Add a splash of reserved pasta water and cooked spaghetti.
4) Sprinkle grated pecorino while tossing vigorously until creamy. Adjust consistency with more pasta water if needed.
5) Serve immediately with extra cheese and pepper on top.

name: Butter Paratha
steps: 1) In a bowl, mix wheat flour, salt, and water as needed to form a soft dough. Rest for 10 minutes.
2) Roll the dough into a round shape using dry flour.
3) Cook on a hot tawa, apply butter or ghee on both sides, and roast until golden spots appear.
4) Serve hot with pickle, curd, or chai.

name: Banana Pancake
steps: 1) Mash the ripe banana in a bowl until smooth.
2) Add the egg and whisk together until well combined.
3) Heat butter or oil in a non-stick pan and pour small rounds of the mixture.
4) Cook on medium flame until golden on both sides. Serve warm.

name: Scrambled Eggs
steps: 1) Crack eggs into a bowl and whisk lightly with salt.
2) Heat butter in a pan, pour in the eggs, and stir continuously until soft and fluffy.

name: Bhakri
steps: 1) Boil water until hot (not boiling vigorously). In a mixing bowl, add jowar flour and a pinch of salt if desired.
2) Gradually pour hot water into the flour while stirring with a spoon. Once slightly cool, knead with hands into a smooth, soft dough.
3) Divide the dough into equal portions and shape into balls.
4) Sprinkle dry jowar flour on the surface. Flatten one ball with your palms and gently roll into a thick circle, about 6–7 inches wide.
5) Heat a tawa or flat pan over medium heat. Place the bhakri on it and cook for 30–40 seconds until small bubbles appear.
6) Flip it and press gently with a cloth or spatula so it puffs up. Cook until brown spots appear on both sides.
7) Optionally, roast directly over flame for a few seconds to make it fluffier.
8) Brush lightly with ghee if desired and serve hot with zunka, thecha, or pitla.

name: Thecha
steps: 1) Heat 1 tbsp oil in a small pan on medium flame. Add cumin seeds (if using) and let them splutter.
2) Add green chilies and garlic cloves. Sauté for 3–4 minutes until the chilies blister and garlic turns slightly golden.
3) Remove from heat and allow to cool slightly.
4) In a mortar and pestle or grinder, crush the sautéed mixture coarsely along with roasted peanuts and salt. Do not make it too smooth — a coarse texture gives authentic taste.
5) Taste and adjust salt if needed. Optionally drizzle a few drops of raw groundnut oil for added aroma.
6) Serve immediately with bhakri, jowar roti, or simple dal-chawal. It can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

name: Bharli Vangi
steps: 1) Wash and slit each brinjal into a cross shape (keeping the stem intact) so they can be stuffed.
2) In a pan, dry roast grated coconut, sesame seeds, and peanuts until lightly golden. Cool and grind coarsely.
3) In a bowl, mix the ground mixture with onion, godā masala, red chili powder, turmeric, ginger-garlic paste, tamarind pulp, jaggery, and salt. Add a few drops of oil to bind the filling.
4) Stuff each brinjal carefully with this masala mixture. Keep any leftover stuffing aside.
5) Heat 3 tbsp oil in a heavy-bottomed pan or kadhai. Place the stuffed brinjals gently in the oil and sauté for 2–3 minutes on medium heat.
6) Add the leftover masala mixture to the pan and sprinkle 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook on low flame for 15–20 minutes, turning the brinjals occasionally until soft and well-cooked.
7) Once the oil separates and the masala thickens, turn off the heat.
8) Garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot with bhakri, chapati, or steamed rice.

name: Puran Poli

ingredients.name: water
ingredients.note: as required to knead the dough

steps: 1) Wash and soak chana dal for 30 minutes. Pressure cook with 2 cups of water until soft but not mushy (about 3–4 whistles). Drain excess water.

2) Transfer the cooked dal to a pan. Add grated jaggery and cook over medium heat, stirring continuously, until the mixture thickens and leaves the sides of the pan. This is the puran (sweet filling).
3) Add cardamom and nutmeg powder. Mix well and let it cool completely. Mash or blend lightly to get a smooth filling.
4) In a mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour, maida, turmeric, salt, and 2 tbsp oil/ghee. Gradually add water to knead a soft, pliable dough. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.
5) Divide both dough and puran into equal lemon-sized portions.
6) Roll out one dough ball slightly, place a portion of puran in the center, and seal the edges to enclose the filling.
7) Gently roll it into a flat circle (6–7 inches) dusting with dry flour as needed.
8) Heat a tawa (griddle). Roast the poli on medium flame until golden brown spots appear on both sides, applying ghee while roasting.
9) Serve warm with a dollop of ghee or milk on the side. Puran Poli tastes best when slightly warm.

name: Appam with Vegetable Stew
steps: 1) Soak 2 cups of raw rice for 4–5 hours.
2) Drain and grind the soaked rice along with 0.5 cup grated coconut, 0.25 cup cooked rice, sugar, and water to a smooth batter.
3) Add 0.5 tsp yeast dissolved in 2 tbsp warm water to the batter and mix well.
4) Cover and ferment overnight or 8 hours until the batter doubles and becomes slightly bubbly.
5) Add salt before making appams and mix gently.
6) Heat an appachatti (appam pan), grease lightly with oil, and pour a ladleful of batter.
7) Swirl the pan so that the batter spreads around the edges with a thicker center.
8) Cover and cook on low heat for 2–3 minutes until the edges are crisp and the center is soft and cooked.
9) Remove the appam gently and keep warm.
10) To prepare the stew, heat 1 tbsp coconut oil in a pan and add sliced onions, green chilies, and ginger.
11) Sauté for a minute, then add curry leaves and mixed vegetables.
12) Add a pinch of salt and 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook until vegetables are tender.
13) Add thick coconut milk and pepper powder. Mix well and simmer on low flame for 2 minutes. Do not boil.
14) Turn off the heat and drizzle a few drops of coconut oil on top.
15) Serve hot appams with warm vegetable stew.

name: Pongal
steps: 1) Dry roast 0.5 cup moong dal in a pan for 3–4 minutes until it turns slightly golden and aromatic.
2) Wash 1 cup rice and add it to the roasted moong dal in a pressure cooker.
3) Pour 4 cups of water and add salt to taste.
4) Close the lid and pressure cook for 4–5 whistles on medium flame.
5) Once the pressure releases, open the cooker and mash the mixture lightly to get a soft, porridge-like texture.
6) In a separate pan, heat 3 tbsp ghee.
7) Add cumin seeds, crushed peppercorns, chopped ginger, and curry leaves. Sauté for 20–30 seconds.
8) Add cashew nuts and fry until golden brown.
9) Pour this tempering over the cooked rice-dal mixture and mix well.
10) Adjust consistency with hot water if needed and mix gently.
11) Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Zunka
steps: 1) Heat 2 tbsp oil in a kadhai or pan over medium flame. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
2) Add curry leaves and chopped onions. Sauté for 3–4 minutes until onions turn translucent.
3) Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
4) Reduce the heat to low. Sprinkle in the gram flour (besan) gradually while stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
5) Lightly sprinkle a few tablespoons of water to moisten the mixture. Keep stirring so the besan cooks evenly.
6) Continue cooking on low heat for 8–10 minutes, stirring every minute until the besan becomes dry, crumbly, and aromatic.
7) Turn off the heat. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
8) Serve hot with bhakri, roti, or rice and a side of thecha or pickle.

name: Upma
steps: 1) Dry roast 1 cup semolina on low heat for 5–6 minutes until aromatic and lightly golden. Transfer to a bowl and set aside.
2) Heat 2 tbsp oil or ghee in a pan on medium flame.
3) Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
4) Add urad dal, chana dal, and cashew nuts. Fry until they turn golden.
5) Add curry leaves, green chilies, and chopped ginger. Sauté for 20–30 seconds.
6) Add finely chopped onions and cook until they turn soft and translucent.
7) Add 2 cups of water and salt to taste. Bring it to a boil.
8) Once the water starts boiling, gradually add roasted semolina while stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
9) Reduce the flame to low and cook for 3–4 minutes until the water is absorbed and the mixture thickens.
10) Turn off the heat, add lemon juice if desired, and mix gently.
11) Garnish with chopped coriander and serve hot.

name: Kanda Bhaji
steps: 1) Mix sliced onions with gram flour, red chili powder, and salt.
2) Add little water as needed to form a thick coating batter.
3) Heat oil in a deep pan. Drop small portions of batter and fry until golden brown.
4) Serve hot with chutney or tea.

name: Masala Dosa
steps: 1) Wash and soak 2 cups rice, 0.5 cup urad dal, 2 tbsp chana dal, and 0.5 tsp fenugreek seeds separately for 5–6 hours.
2) Grind the urad dal into a fluffy batter with little water, then grind the rice and chana dal mixture coarsely.
3) Combine both batters, mix well, and let it ferment overnight or 8–10 hours until doubled in volume.
4) Add salt to the fermented batter and mix gently.
5) To prepare the potato masala, heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan, add mustard seeds, and let them splutter.
6) Add curry leaves, green chilies, and grated ginger. Sauté for a few seconds.
7) Add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
8) Add turmeric powder and the boiled, mashed potatoes. Mix well and add little water if needed.
9) Cook for 3–4 minutes, add salt to taste, and turn off the heat. The masala is ready.
10) Heat a non-stick or cast-iron tawa. Pour a ladleful of batter in the center and spread it thin in a circular motion.
11) Drizzle some oil or ghee around the edges and cook until golden and crisp.
12) Place a spoonful of potato masala in the center, fold the dosa, and serve hot.
13) Serve with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Tomato Saar
steps: 1) Boil chopped tomatoes with 1 cup of water until soft. Blend into a smooth puree.
2) Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds and crushed garlic; sauté until fragrant.
3) Pour in the tomato puree, add salt, and simmer for 5 minutes.
4) Serve hot with rice or sip as a light soup.

name: Batata Bhaji
steps: 1) Heat oil in a pan over medium flame. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
2) Add green chilies and sauté for a few seconds.
3) Add turmeric powder and mix quickly.
4) Add boiled diced potatoes and salt. Mix well.
5) Cook for 3–4 minutes while stirring gently. Serve hot with chapati or poori.

name: Medu Vada
steps: 1) Wash and soak 1 cup urad dal in enough water for 4 hours.
2) Drain and grind the soaked dal with minimal water into a thick, fluffy batter.
3) Beat the batter with your hand or spoon for 2–3 minutes to incorporate air and make it light.
4) Add finely chopped green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, crushed pepper, onion (optional), and salt to the batter. Mix well.
5) Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame until hot.
6) Wet your palms, take a small portion of batter, shape it into a doughnut with a hole in the center, and carefully slide it into the oil.
7) Fry 3–4 vadas at a time until golden brown and crisp on both sides.
8) Remove onto absorbent paper to drain excess oil.
9) Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Idli
steps: 1) Rinse the idli rice and urad dal separately 2–3 times. Soak rice with fenugreek seeds in enough water for 6 hours. Soak urad dal separately for 4 hours.
2) Drain the soaked urad dal and grind it with a little water until smooth, light, and fluffy. Transfer to a large bowl.
3) Drain the rice and grind it with just enough water to make a slightly coarse batter. Combine both batters in a large vessel and mix well with your hand.
4) Cover and ferment the batter in a warm place for 8–12 hours, or until it doubles in volume and turns slightly airy.
5) Once fermented, gently stir in salt. Do not overmix or deflate the batter.
6) Grease idli moulds with a little oil and pour the batter into each mould, filling about ¾ of the way.
7) Steam in an idli steamer or pressure cooker (without the whistle) for 10–12 minutes on medium heat until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
8) Remove the moulds and let them rest for 2–3 minutes. Then unmould the idlis using a wet spoon.
9) Serve hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or milagai podi.

name: Kanda Pohe
steps: 1) Preparation: Place 2 cups of thick poha in a large sieve or colander. Rinse gently under running water for 10–15 seconds. Do not soak. Let it sit for 10 minutes to soften naturally. After resting, sprinkle a few tablespoons of water if it feels dry. Mix in salt, sugar (if using), and turmeric powder directly into the poha and fluff with a spoon.
2) Tempering: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a heavy-bottomed kadhai or non-stick pan over medium heat. Add 3 tbsp peanuts and roast them until golden and crisp. Remove and set aside.
3) In the same oil, add 0.5 tsp mustard seeds. When they start to pop, add curry leaves and green chilies. Sauté for 15–20 seconds until fragrant.
4) Add the chopped onions and cook for 3–4 minutes until they turn translucent (not browned).
5) Add the softened poha mixture and gently toss everything together using a flat spatula. Add roasted peanuts back in. Mix well but avoid breaking the poha flakes.
6) Cover and steam on low heat for 2–3 minutes. This allows the flavors to combine and the poha to become fluffy.
7) Turn off the heat. Add lemon juice and chopped coriander. Mix lightly.
8) Garnish with grated coconut (optional) and serve hot immediately with extra lemon wedges and a cup of hot chai.

name: Pav Bhaji
steps: 1) Make the masala from scratch (optional but recommended): In a small dry pan on medium heat, toast 1 tbsp coriander seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp fennel seeds, 4–5 black peppercorns, 3 dried red chilies, 1/2 inch cinnamon stick, 2 cloves and 1 bay leaf for 2–3 minutes until fragrant. Cool, then grind to a fine powder. Mix in 1 tsp amchur (dry mango powder) if using. Store — this yields about 2–3 tbsp of fresh masala.

2) Prep vegetables: Peel and roughly chop potatoes and carrot. Break cauliflower into small florets. Finely chop 1 onion for bhaji and thinly slice the other (for faster cooking you can keep both chopped). Roughly chop tomatoes. Crush garlic and grate or finely chop ginger. Finely chop coriander and slit the green chili.

3) Par-cook root vegetables: In a pressure cooker or large pot, add potatoes, cauliflower, carrot and peas with 1/2 tsp salt and enough water to cover. Cook until soft (2 whistles in a cooker or 12–15 minutes simmer). Drain and reserve the cooking liquid. Coarsely mash the cooked vegetables with a potato masher — leave it slightly coarse (not fully smooth).

4) Cook the bhaji base: In a heavy-bottomed pan or kadhai, heat 2 tbsp butter + 1 tbsp oil on medium heat (oil prevents butter from burning). Add 0.5 tsp cumin seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent and beginning to brown (6–8 minutes).

5) Add aromatics and tomatoes: Add crushed garlic, chopped ginger and slit green chili. Sauté 1–2 minutes until raw smell goes. Add the chopped tomatoes and a pinch of salt; cook until tomatoes are soft and oil starts to separate (8–10 minutes). You can mash tomatoes with the back of a spoon while cooking.

6) Spice it: Add 1–2 tsp of the freshly ground pav bhaji masala (or 2 tbsp if using store-bought), 1 tsp red chilli powder, 1 tsp coriander powder and 1/4 tsp turmeric. Cook the spices with the tomato-onion mixture for 1–2 minutes so the raw spice taste disappears.

7) Combine vegetables and simmer: Add the mashed vegetables to the pan. Mix thoroughly. Add 1 cup of reserved cooking liquid (or water) to loosen the mixture. Bring to a gentle boil, then reduce heat and simmer, mashing the mixture against the side of the pan with a masher to make a smooth-but-textured gravy. Add salt to taste.

8) Finish with butter and adjust: Add remaining 2 tbsp butter and 1 tsp kasuri methi (crushed) if using. Simmer on low for 8–10 minutes, stirring and mashing occasionally. If bhaji is too thick, add a little hot water. Taste and adjust spices, salt and lemon.

9) Toast the pav: Heat a flat tawa or skillet. Slice pav horizontally (not all the way through). Add a knob of butter and place pav on tawa cut-side down, press lightly and toast until golden and crisp on both sides. For extra flavor, sprinkle a tiny pinch of pav bhaji masala on the butter before toasting.

10) Serve: Transfer bhaji to a serving bowl, garnish generously with chopped coriander and a knob of butter on top. Serve hot with toasted buttered pav, lemon wedges and finely chopped onions on the side.
11) Vegan option: Replace butter with vegan butter or extra oil. Reduce or omit kasuri methi if unavailable.
12) Storage & reheating: Store bhaji in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days. Reheat on low with a splash of water and a pat of butter or oil to restore richness.
13) Scaling: This recipe scales well — double quantities for a larger crowd. If using store-bought pav bhaji masala, start with 2 tbsp and adjust to taste.
